title: Morning Defense
description: From the SitRoom to the E-Ring, the inside scoop on defense, national security and foreign policy.

entries.title: Ukraine wants more than a D-day speech from Biden
entries.description: There are a few recent moves by Biden that have led to this sense of skepticism in Kyiv.

entries.title: Why Biden may stay ‘uncertain’ about Israeli actions
entries.description: The accusations against Israel are numerous.

entries.title: The other border crisis Biden needs to worry about
entries.description: Today, South Korea officially suspended its peace agreement with North Korea, a deal which had essentially been dead anyways.

entries.title: Here’s what is complicating the cease-fire deal
entries.description: It’s hard to trust what either side is saying right now, since both Israel and Hamas are angling for outcomes that fit their own interests, experts say.

entries.title: ‘No evidence’ Biden’s Sudan policy is working
entries.description: The Biden administration's efforts to bring Sudan’s devastating civil war to an end aren’t getting very far — and top lawmakers on both sides of the aisle want the U.S. to change course.

entries.title: Biden secretly allowed Ukraine to strike inside Russia
entries.description: It's a major reversal that will help Ukraine to better defend its second-largest city, following hints from top Biden aides that the U.S. would consider the move this week.

entries.title: Why Putin’s next target could be the Balkans
entries.description: Other European nations in Russia’s backyard have publicly voiced their concerns about Putin’s growing aggression toward its neighbors.

entries.title: Washington grows isolated with Israel after Rafah strikes
entries.description: Washington’s closest allies are striking a stark contrast, underscoring how staunchly President Joe Biden supports Israel no matter how its actions are viewed on the world stage.

entries.title: Critical Gaza aid crossing to reopen as famine looms
entries.description: In a promising development for aid this afternoon, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi agreed to resume aid truck deliveries into Rafah during a phone call with President Joe Biden.

entries.title: A new military era for the US and Kenya, kind of?
entries.description: Kenya has proven itself a valuable partner for the U.S.

entries.title: Palestinian statehood a ‘ripple’ for now — that still worries the White House
entries.description: Today, Spain, Norway and Ireland said they would officially recognize Palestine as a state next Tuesday, drawing a line between Palestine and Israel based on the borders from before 1967.

entries.title: The escalating fight over Haiti ahead of Ruto’s visit
entries.description: For months, Michael McCaul and Jim Risch have been a pain for the Biden administration on Haiti, blocking funds the White House says are necessary to bolster Kenyan forces.

entries.title: Biden’s latest Bibi problem is a big one
entries.description: The tensions around an ICC decision could spell trouble for Biden.

entries.title: China’s big moves in the Indo-Pacific
entries.description: In the next few days, the Chinese landing vessel Jinggangshan and training ship Qijiguang will visit Ream for exercises with Cambodian cadets.

entries.title: Options narrow for Palestinians looking to escape Gaza
entries.description: If fighting in Rafah continues, any progress made with humanitarian aid efforts could be lost, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Wednesday.

entries.title: Ukraine’s new pressure campaign at a possible turning point
entries.description: There are signs that the U.S. is listening.

entries.title: US lawmakers blamed for Georgia’s unrest
entries.description: Countries bordering Russia could increasingly cozy up to the Kremlin if the war continues to shift in Russian President Vladimir Putin's favor, three experts told NatSec Daily.

entries.title: Russia’s war economy takes the front seat
entries.description: Kyiv believes the move shows Moscow may be “preparing for a protracted war,” according to a Ukrainian document setting out talking points for government officials today, obtained by NatSec Daily.

entries.title: There’s growing ‘hatred toward the West’
entries.description: Bafel Talabani touched on the main issues playing out in the Middle East — and how they affect Washington.

entries.title: Israel has gone into Rafah. Where’s the ‘red line’?
entries.description: National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby told reporters today that a major operation would be recognizable by the movements of many forces and damage to civilian infrastructure “as opposed to more precise, more targeted” operations.

entries.title: A pain in the assets for Russia
entries.description: Poland has been outspoken about punishing Russia for its full-scale invasion of Ukraine since the start.

entries.title: More resignations over Israel and ‘a failed policy’
entries.description: The State Department was expected to issue a report on Wednesday about whether Israel has violated international humanitarian law since the war in Gaza began.

entries.title: About that Hamas cease-fire proposal…
entries.description: From what it sounds like, there are at least two proposals on the table, neither of which Israel and Hamas agree on.

entries.title: Israel normalization with Saudi likely not ‘ripe’
entries.description: The U.S. wants Saudi normalization with Israel, but Israel probably won’t want to pay too high of a price.

entries.title: Why the Swedes are still hopeful in Ukraine
entries.description: In an interview with NatSec Daily the supreme commander of Sweden’s armed forces said he’s aware that Ukraine faces a tough challenge in fighting back against Russia, but emphasized that “so far, they have proven to do very well.”

entries.title: Does Israel dissent matter to Biden?
entries.description: The White House likely isn’t losing sleep over internal dissent, despite major headlines whenever an official resigns or pens an anonymous letter bashing its policy.

entries.title: Rafah invasion could derail cease-fire talks, aid groups warn
entries.description: Today, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel will move on the city, regardless of whether Hamas agrees to the latest Israeli proposal for a cease-fire.

entries.title: Kenyan forces are about to land in Haiti — with nowhere clear to stay
entries.description: When the first forces step foot in Haiti, they also might not have a place to go.

entries.title: Israel: ‘Investigate what?’
entries.description: "We don’t bury people in mass graves. Not something we do,” said Israel Defense Forces spokesperson Nadav Shoshani.

entries.title: US doesn't know if Hamas is ‘stringing out’ hostage talks
entries.description: But there are few signs an agreement is getting any closer.
